Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructorâ€™s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: GHGs in lower atmosphere - are they harmless?
Input.posts:
In the layer model, greenhouse gases near ground level correspond to panes of glass near ground level, and their impact on surface temperature is to impede the flow of heat upward. However, if I understand the lectures of week 2 properly, heat flows freely upward by convection to the height of the tropopause, and the radiation absorption properties of the lower atmosphere has no impact on the temperature profile and heat flow up to that level. So, it would seem, only CO2 near or above the skin layer is effective in raising the altitude and depressing the temperature of the skin. For CO2, this doesn't matter so much, because the CO2 concentration will be constant with altitude. But water (because it has condensed out) and methane (because it is destroyed by stratospheric OH, O, and O3) will have lower concentrations at high altitude than near the surface. So, it would seem, they are less effective as GHGs than might be thought at first from lab measurements. Is this analysis correct?

The GHGs near the surface radiate downwards and add to the surface energy budget. In the MODTRAN online model, you can test the effect of varying the GHG values by first setting the altitude to 0km and switch from 'looking down' to 'looking up'. In the tropical setting the downward radiation is 348.23 W/M2 at 400ppm CO2 and 350.11 at 800Oppm CO2. Try it for different settings, it has a definite effect, so it is not 'harmless'.

0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi James, I agree with you that GHGs closer to the Earth's surface are less effective because temperature decreases with altitude, but I think I'd make a slight modification to your statement that 'only CO2 near or above the skin layer is effective ...' I'd say CO2 near the skin layer is more effective than CO2 near the ground. The efficacy of CO2 grows in with altitude because the temperature starts dropping right away as you go up. So, you're right that H2O and CH4 would be less effective than might be thought from lab measurements - if the lab measurements don't include effects of concentration/temperature/altitude. A good model of the greenhouse effect would have to look at the temperature and concentration of GHGs as a function of altitude.

Input.threadtitle: On greenhouse gas physics: Is there a limit?
Input.posts:
Based on the 'Greenhouse Gas Physics' video lecture, I wonder on the limit of a greenhouse gas to absorb energy, and the impact of the molecular complex structure on absorbing and emitting energy. CH4 has four atoms of hydrogen and CO2 has two atoms of oxygen, but they both share one atom of carbon: Â¿ Which molecule requires a higher frequency to absorb energy ?, Â¿ has the linkage strength between atoms something to do with the capacity to absorb energy ?.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Adrian, The number of vibrational modes a molecule has is equal to 3N - 6 (or 3N - 5 if molecule is linear, like CO2), where N is the number of atoms in the molecule. The frequency of each mode is given by the square root of (k / mu), where k is (roughly) the bond strength between the atoms that are vibrating (or bending), and mu is the reduced mass of the vibrational mode ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reduced_mass ). CO2 has 4 vibrational modes with frequencies: 526 cm-1, 526 cm-1, 1480 cm-1, and 2565 cm-1. As we saw in lecture, the 1480 cm-1 mode is IR-inactive. CH4 has 9 vibrational modes with frequencies: 3087 cm-1, 3087 cm-1, 3087 cm-1, 2972 cm-1, 1508 cm-1, 1508 cm-1, 1285 cm-1, 1285 cm-1, 1285 cm-1. 6 of these are IR-active, but because many of the frequencies are the same, it only has 2 distinct frequencies. There probably is some sort of limit for the highest attainable IR-active frequency, although I'm not sure what molecule you'd find it in. Something with a large k and a small mu, maybe something like HF (hydrogen fluoride)?

Input.threadtitle: Tropopause - why is there one?
Input.posts:
The tropopause seems to be defined as the altitude at which the lapse rate changes from its tropospheric value of 5-10 deg-K/km to a value near zero or even negative. But the lectures did not explain what physical or chemical difference in the atmosphere causes this change. Is it that this is the level above which the atmosphere is heated by uv? In any case, I am puzzled as to what would happen if GHG concentrations became high enough to move the 'skin' height above the tropopause.
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi James, Exactly right. Ozone in the stratosphere (above the tropopause) absorbs UV. I don't know for sure, but I doubt that moving the skin height above the tropopause would have much of an effect (if at all) on the greenhouse effect. The air up there is so thin, most of the IR going out to space would be originating from the troposphere anyway, where it is cooler than at the Earth's surface. And, you'd have to go pretty far up to start to see temperatures close to what they are at Earth's surface.
